flow.context: Zack is an Operations Manager at Kiawah Exclusives, the Kiawah Island arm of Kiawah Seabrook Exclusives — roughly 115+ rentals on Kiawah, 185+ total across both islands. He owns day-to-day field execution: vendor dispatch, punch lists, making sure every property is inspected and prepped after each cleaning. The company already runs a 25-point checklist with photo verification at every turnover and uses Track as their PMS. They were acquired by Continuum Management Group in 2021, so there is likely pressure to standardize quality reporting across the portfolio. Zack works under Director of Operations Ryan and GM Karen McFadden, alongside another Ops Manager named Chandler. His happy place is snow-covered Colorado mountains — Sam just skied Jackson Hole in January, which is a natural rapport hook if the conversation opens up.

gatekeeper_initial.label: GATEKEEPER — SLIDE BY
gatekeeper_initial.say: Hey, could you get me over to Zack? It's Sam.
gatekeeper_initial.note: Say it like you belong. Don't offer more info. Pause and wait for a response.

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other vacation rental teams in the area on their inspection workflows. Would you mind letting Zack know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Stay casual. Don't pitch. You're just a person trying to reach a person. End with a redirect question so you stay in control.

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Totally understand. We help a couple other property management companies in the Lowcountry with their turnover inspection process — I sent Zack a note and just wanted to give him a heads up. Would you mind passing that along?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: This is your last play. If they still block, get a callback time or pivot to leaving a message. Don't get confrontational.

gatekeeper_leave_message.label: LEAVE MESSAGE
gatekeeper_leave_message.say: That'd be great — just Sam Parks, RapidEye. He can reach me at my direct line. And hey, what's the best time to catch him at his desk? I'll try back then.
gatekeeper_leave_message.note: Always get a callback window. A name and a time — that's all you need. Log it immediately.

gatekeeper_not_available.label: ZACK UNAVAILABLE
gatekeeper_not_available.say: No worries at all. Is there a better time to catch him — mornings, afternoons? I'm flexible, whatever works best for his schedule.
gatekeeper_not_available.note: Get a specific window. If they offer Chandler or Ryan instead, take that call — both are also good targets in this org.

branches.label: Gives you a time to call back
Offers another ops person like Chandler or Ryan

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Zack — I've been working with a few other vacation rental ops teams down in the Lowcountry. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Relaxed. Feet up on the desk energy. Slight smile in your voice. Don't rush the 'have you heard my name' — pause after it and let him respond. You're calling the main Kiawah line so he may have just been transferred; match his energy.

branches.label: No / who? / doesn't ring a bell
Bad timing / busy / in the field

heard_yes.label: HEARD YES
heard_yes.say: Oh nice — well usually we'd be working with someone in your role. What'd you hear?
heard_yes.note: Let him talk. Whatever he says, bridge it to the pain trigger or discovery. Don't correct anything — just flow with it and learn what he already knows.

branches.label: Confused / vague / mixing it up with something else

heard_no.label: HEARD NO
heard_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well, the reason for my call is actually pretty specific to you —
heard_no.note: Quick self-deprecating beat, then immediately transition into the pain trigger. No pause for permission here — you've earned the next sentence with the laugh.

branches.label: Cuts you off / 'what do you want?'

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — sounds like you're in the middle of it. Would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe first thing before the day gets crazy?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. If he's in the field doing turnovers right now, that actually validates the pain. Note it and use it as the opener on the callback: 'Last time I called you were neck-deep in turns.'

callback_schedule.label: CALLBACK LOCKED
callback_schedule.say: Perfect — I'll hit you up then. Appreciate it, Zack. Talk soon.
callback_schedule.note: Repeat the exact day and time back to confirm. Put it in your calendar immediately. When you call back, open with: 'Hey Zack, it's Sam — you told me to call you back today.'

permission_ask.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_ask.say: Yeah totally — I mean it is a cold call, I'll own that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I called you specifically, and if it's not relevant you can absolutely hang up on me?
permission_ask.note: This is the fallback when the opener doesn't land. Honesty disarms skepticism. Emphasize 'you specifically' — that signals this isn't a blast dial and you did your homework.

branches.label: Fine / go ahead / you've got 30 seconds

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot — totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you're already set on your inspection process and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: You're splitting the rejection into two buckets. Most people will clarify, and that clarification reopens the door. Either answer gives you a path forward.

branches.label: We're already set / have a process

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So I was talking to another ops manager at a vacation rental company pretty similar to yours — about a hundred-plus homes, beach market, full-service. And he was telling me how after every turnover his team's collecting all these photos for their checklist — like 20, 25 shots per clean — and technically someone's supposed to review every single one before the next guest walks in. But when you've got 15 turns on a Saturday in July, nobody's catching a hairline crack in a countertop in photo 22 of unit 47. Guest checks in, finds it, calls in — now it's a damage dispute, the owner's asking why nobody caught it, and it's his team that takes the heat. He said it was eating him alive.
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE HERE. Do not fill the silence. You just described Zack's exact life — 115+ Kiawah properties, 25-point checklist with photo verification, peak season volume. Let him react. The silence is where the sale happens.

branches.label: Pushback — 'we've got that handled' / 'not really our issue'
'That's not really my area' / defers to someone else

pain_resonates.label: PAIN RESONATES
pain_resonates.say: Yeah — I figured that might hit close to home with 115-plus properties on Kiawah alone. Before I say anything else — what does your turnover process actually look like right now? Like, who's reviewing those photos after the cleaners submit them?
pain_resonates.note: HE'S WARM. Stop pitching immediately. Ask questions. Learn his specific workflow, what tools they use, where the gaps are. Every detail he shares makes the meeting easier to book and the demo easier to personalize.

branches.label: Describes their process / opens up about workflow
Short answer, then asks what you do

pain_neutral.label: PAIN NEUTRAL — PUSH FORWARD
pain_neutral.say: The thing is — his team was already doing the right stuff. They had the checklist, the photos, the whole process. The problem wasn't the process — it was that no human can actually review 400 photos on a turnover day and catch everything. So we built something that does that automatically — an AI that analyzes every turnover photo and flags damage, missing items, staging issues. Plugs right into Track, no workflow change for your team.
pain_neutral.note: He's not sold but he's not gone. Combine the solution with the pain in one push. Mentioning Track by name shows you did your homework and makes it feel turnkey, not theoretical.

branches.label: Interest — 'how does that work?' / 'wait, we use Track'

solution_drop.label: SOLUTION — ONE SENTENCE
solution_drop.say: So we built an AI that plugs into Track — it analyzes every turnover photo your team's already taking and automatically flags damage, missing items, staging issues. No workflow change, no extra steps for your cleaners or inspectors. It just catches the stuff that slips through at volume.
solution_drop.note: One breath. Don't oversell. Mentioning Track by name signals you understand their setup. Immediately transition to the CTA — don't wait for a reaction to the product description.

branches.label: Skeptical about AI / 'we've seen stuff like this'

cta.label: LOW-FRICTION CTA
cta.say: Would you be open to taking a look at it — not right now obviously, but when I'm not cold calling you out of the blue? Even if it's just to see what other PM companies in your market are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
cta.note: This is your close. Keep it light. No pressure. 'Steal some ideas' reframes the meeting as valuable even if they never buy. If he says yes, go straight to booking — don't keep pitching.

branches.label: Sure / I'd be open to that

warm_discovery.label: DISCOVERY — ASK QUESTIONS
warm_discovery.say: That's really helpful. So when a photo flags something — like damage that wasn't there before — what happens next? Is that going to you and Chandler directly, or does Ryan triage that?
warm_discovery.note: You know the team: Zack + Chandler are both Ops Managers, Ryan is Director of Ops, Debbie runs housekeeping on Kiawah, Rene is the inspector on the Seabrook side. Drop names naturally if he mentions them first. Goal: understand the escalation chain and where things break down.

branches.label: Describes the flow / shares frustrations openly
Surprised you know names — 'how do you know Chandler?'
Cuts it short — 'what's this gonna cost me?'

deeper_discovery.label: DEEPER DISCOVERY
deeper_discovery.say: Got it. And with Continuum now owning the portfolio — are they pushing for any kind of standardized reporting on property condition across markets, or is it still pretty much local decisions?
deeper_discovery.note: This question shows you understand their corporate structure. If Continuum is driving standardization, RapidEye becomes a portfolio-wide play worth mentioning to their COO Stacy Charlton. If it's still local, keep it tactical for Zack's world. Either answer helps you position.

branches.label: Yes — Continuum wants reporting or standardization
Doesn't want to get into corporate stuff

continuum_angle.label: CONTINUUM CORPORATE ANGLE
continuum_angle.say: That's actually perfect context. A few of the PM companies we work with are in the same setup — local operations, corporate parent wanting data and dashboards. The reports our AI generates roll up pretty cleanly for that kind of portfolio-level visibility. Would it make sense to loop in whoever on the Continuum side cares about that when we set up time?
continuum_angle.note: This is the multi-brand expansion play. If he names Stacy Charlton (COO) or Ryan Greer (Director of Ops at Continuum), write it down. Don't push — just plant the seed. Even if he says 'let's start local,' that's a win.

branches.label: That could make sense / names someone at Continuum
Let's start with just us first
Not sure / would have to ask

explain_research.label: EXPLAIN HOW YOU KNOW
explain_research.say: Ha — yeah, I did my homework. Your team page's actually pretty solid. I figured if I'm gonna call you I should at least know who I'm talking to and not waste your time with something generic.
explain_research.note: Full honesty. He'll respect the prep. Don't be weird about it — keep it light and transition back to discovery or CTA.

handle_skepticism.label: HANDLE AI SKEPTICISM
handle_skepticism.say: Totally fair — there's a ton of AI noise right now, I get it. The difference is we're not asking your team to do anything different. Your cleaners already take photos, your inspectors already check units. We just analyze what's already being captured and surface the stuff a human eye would miss when you're reviewing hundreds of photos in a day. We're running this for a PM company with 600 properties on the East Coast right now — so it's not theoretical.
handle_skepticism.note: Ground it in reality: existing workflow, real customers, real scale. Don't get defensive about the AI label — acknowledge the noise, then differentiate with specifics.

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — ALREADY HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 115-plus properties you'd have to have a solid system in place. I'd honestly be worried if you didn't.
objection_have_process.note: AGREE first. Validate their competence. Don't fight it. The agreement surprises them and lowers their guard. Then split the objection.

split_have_process.label: SPLIT — PROCESS OBJECTION
split_have_process.say: Just so I'm not bugging you again — is it that you're fully covered and the photo review process is working exactly the way you want it? Or is it more that adding anything new right now would be a headache, especially heading into season?
split_have_process.note: Most ops managers will admit their process isn't perfect if you give them a safe way to say it. 'Heading into season' shows you understand their calendar and creates urgency without being pushy.

branches.label: Switching or adding tools is the issue
Genuinely covered and happy with everything

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool you already have, let alone buy something new — especially when budgets are probably running through Continuum now too.
objection_no_budget.note: Agree and show you understand their corporate structure. The Continuum reference signals you know purchasing decisions might not be purely local anymore, which builds credibility.

branches.label: Corrects you on how budget works

split_no_budget.label: SPLIT — BUDGET OBJECTION
split_no_budget.say: Just so nobody from my team cold calls you again — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked down, or is it more that anything new you try to bring in puts you through the ringer with approvals?
split_no_budget.note: Both answers give you a path. 'Locked' means revisit next cycle — get permission to follow up. 'Ringer' means help him build the internal case — that's what the meeting is for.

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Look — you're probably not buying anything off a cold call, and I totally respect that. But when budget does open up or you're evaluating tools, the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's on their list. Would you be open to a 20-minute look — not a sales pitch, just a walkthrough of what we're doing and what other PM companies in Charleston are doing with their turnover photos? Worst case you steal some ideas for your own process.
sell_test_drive.note: Reframes the meeting as intelligence-gathering, not a buying decision. '20 minutes' is a small commitment. 'Steal some ideas' makes it safe. If he bites, go straight to booking — do not keep selling.

branches.label: Not right now / maybe down the road

last_resort_value.label: LAST VALUE OFFER
last_resort_value.say: Totally fair. If nothing else — I've got a breakdown of what the top PM companies in the Charleston market are doing differently with their inspection workflows. Happy to send it your way, no strings attached. At least it'd be useful even if we never talk again. Cool if I shoot that over?
last_resort_value.note: Give something of genuine value. If he gives you his email, you have a warm follow-up channel. Don't push the meeting anymore — you've made your ask.

not_my_call.label: NOT MY DECISION
not_my_call.say: Totally makes sense. Who on your team would typically own a decision like this for the inspection workflow? Would that be Ryan, or does that go up to Karen?
not_my_call.note: You know Ryan is Director of Ops and Karen McFadden is GM. Dropping their names shows deep research and makes the referral frictionless. If he confirms or corrects, take whoever he gives you.

branches.label: Names Ryan or Karen or someone specific
Says he can pass something along himself

referral_ask.label: REFERRAL — OPEN ASK
referral_ask.say: Totally get it — I don't wanna waste your time if this sits above your level. Who'd be the best person to have this conversation with? Someone who owns the inspection workflow and could actually greenlight a tool if it made sense?
referral_ask.note: Non-threatening framing. You're trying to get a name and ideally an intro. If he says Ryan or Karen, you're in great shape — both are primary targets.

branches.label: Won't give a name / doesn't know

referral_get_name.label: REFERRAL — GET CONTACT INFO
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — and if I could get a direct line or email for them, I'll put something specific together so it actually lands instead of being another generic cold pitch. Would you mind sharing that?
referral_get_name.note: Always ask for contact info. If he offers to forward something himself, accept it gratefully but still try to get the direct contact. An intro from Zack is gold.

branches.label: Offers to forward or introduce you

referral_close.label: REFERRAL — CLOSE
referral_close.say: Really appreciate that, Zack. I'll put something together that's specific to your setup — the Track integration, the photo workflow, the volume you guys are running. And hey, if you ever wanna see it yourself, the door's always open. Thanks for your time, man.
referral_close.note: Thank him genuinely. Mentioning Track and their specifics signals to the referred person that 'this guy already knows our operation.' Send the tailored follow-up within the hour while this conversation is fresh.

email_ask.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
email_ask.say: Totally fair — I'll shoot you something. One quick question so it's actually useful and not just another generic pitch sitting in your inbox: what would be most relevant to include? Are you more curious about the AI side and how it actually works, or more about what it'd look like plugged into Track with your current photo process?
email_ask.note: Asking WHAT to include does two things: makes the email actually relevant, and gets him thinking about his own problems. Whatever he answers, that's your email hook and subject line.

branches.label: Tells you what he wants to see

email_close.label: EMAIL — LOCK AND CLOSE
email_close.say: Got it — I'll send that over today. What's the best email for you? And I'll drop in a couple times to connect next week in case anything jumps out. Appreciate your time, Zack.
email_close.note: Get his direct email — don't settle for info@kiawahexclusives.com if you can help it. Always include a specific meeting time suggestion in the email. Send within 30 minutes while the call is fresh in his mind.

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome — let's lock it in right now so it doesn't get lost. I've got next week pulled up. Would a morning work better for you before things get crazy? I'm thinking Tuesday or Thursday.
book_meeting.note: Give two specific options. Don't say 'when works for you' — that creates decision fatigue. Mornings are better for ops managers before the turnover day ramps up. Send the calendar invite WHILE on the phone.

branches.label: Needs to check calendar / not sure yet
Backs off — 'let me think about it'

meeting_followup.label: MEETING — PLACEHOLDER INVITE
meeting_followup.say: No problem — I'll shoot you an invite for Thursday morning as a placeholder and you can move it if you need to. What's the best email for the invite?
meeting_followup.note: Don't let the meeting float without an anchor. A placeholder invite is infinitely better than 'I'll follow up sometime.' Get the email and send the invite before you hang up.

branches.label: Says he'll reach out to you instead

meeting_booked.label: MEETING LOCKED
meeting_booked.say: Perfect — you'll see that invite in a sec. Really appreciate you taking my call, Zack. And hey — next time you're out in the Colorado mountains, let me know. I just got back from Jackson Hole in January and I'm already trying to plan the next one. Talk soon, man.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. The meeting is booked. The mountains comment is a natural rapport closer — his happy place is 'snow-covered Colorado mountains.' Don't force it if the vibe doesn't fit, but if there's a natural beat it's a great human touch to end on. Send the invite immediately.

end_graceful.label: END — GRACEFUL
end_graceful.say: Totally understand, Zack. If anything ever comes up on the inspection side, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time.
end_graceful.note: Don't burn the bridge. Tone should be genuine, not defeated. Log the call, note any intel he shared about their process or team, and set a follow-up reminder for 6-8 weeks out.
